title: 114_hr2365
content: The Act titled "Construction Reform, Authorization, and Choice Improvement Act of 2015" includes reforms for the Department of Veterans Affairs construction projects. The "Construction Reform, Authorization, and Choice Improvement Act of 2015" amends Section 8103 of title 38, United States Code to require project management services for super construction projects and the use of industry standards in constructing medical facilities. Additionally, it limits planning and design for super construction projects under Section 8104(a) of the Code. The amendment to Section 8104(a) of title 38, United States Code, prohibits the Secretary from using funds for advance planning or design of super construction projects until 60 days after notifying the relevant committees. A super construction project refers to medical facility construction, alteration, or acquisition. The Secretary is restricted from obligating funds for a medical facility project exceeding a specified amount without congressional approval. The project cost cannot exceed the approved amount by more than 10 percent without the consent of the Committees on Veterans' Affairs and Appropriations. The Secretary is required to obtain approval from the Committees on Veterans' Affairs and Appropriations before obligating funds for a medical facility project. The Secretary cannot exceed the approved project cost by more than 10 percent without congressional consent. The Committees on Veterans' Affairs and Appropriations of the Senate and House must approve the obligation of funds for medical facility projects. Quarterly report on super construction projects required by the Secretary within 30 days after each fiscal quarter, detailing project reserve amounts, completion percentage, and use of bid savings for purposes other than the project. The Secretary must submit quarterly reports to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs regarding super construction projects, detailing budget and scheduling status, actual cost and schedule variances. The term 'super construction project' is defined in section 8103(a)(4)(C) of this title. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must complete master plans for existing and new medical facilities by specific deadlines. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must complete master plans for existing and new medical facilities to inform investment decisions and funding requests over a 10-year period. The plan aims to meet the healthcare needs of a changing veteran population and maximize the use of land and structures at the facility. SEC. 3 clarifies the distance requirement for expanded availability of hospital care and medical services for veterans through agreements with non-Department of Veterans Affairs entities. The Veterans Access, Choice, and Accountability Act of 2014 is amended to clarify the distance requirement for expanded availability of hospital care and medical services for veterans facing challenges in traveling to medical facilities. The Veterans Access, Choice, and Accountability Act of 2014 is amended to include provisions for individuals with medical conditions affecting their ability to travel or other factors determined by the Secretary. The amendments will take effect upon the enactment of the Act and apply to care or services provided thereafter. SEC. 4. Modification of authorization for a new bed tower at the Department of Veterans Affairs medical center in Tampa, Florida, instead of bed tower upgrades. SEC. 5. Authorization of fiscal year 2015 major medical facility projects. In fiscal year 2015, the Secretary of Veterans Affairs is authorized to carry out major medical facility projects including construction and seismic corrections in various locations such as Canandaigua, New York, Long Beach, West Los Angeles, and San Diego, California. Total funding for these projects is not to exceed specified amounts. Authorization of $561,420,000 for VA major projects in fiscal year 2015. Total funding not to exceed $205,840,000. SEC. 6. Permanent authority for expanded availability of hospital care and medical services for veterans through agreements with non-Department of Veterans Affairs entities. Amends the Veterans Access, Choice, and Accountability Act of 2014 by redesignating subsections and making conforming amendments. SEC. 7. Sense of Congress regarding Veterans Choice Fund. Section 802(e) of the Veterans Access, Choice, and Accountability Act of 2014 is amended by removing references to fiscal years 2015 through 2017.
